content.body: i see in your explicit resource management test262 PR you have a test that `for (using of of [1,2,3]) {}` isn't supposed the parse
content.formatted_body: i see in your explicit resource management test262 PR you have a test that for (using of of [1,2,3]) {} isn't supposed the parse

content.body:
the grammar as i read it says that for the production

for ( [lookahead ≠ using of] ForDeclaration[?Yield, ?Await, +Using] of AssignmentExpression[+In, ?Yield, ?Await] ) Statement[?Yield, ?Await, ?Return]

because of the negative lookahead, `for (using of of [1,2,3]) {}` is always parsed as

for ( [lookahead ∉ { let, async of }] LeftHandSideExpression[?Yield, ?Await] of AssignmentExpression[+In, ?Yield, ?Await] ) Statement[?Yield, ?Await, ?Return]
content.formatted_body:
because of the negative lookahead, for (using of of [1,2,3]) {} is always parsed as

for ( [lookahead ∉ { let, async of }] LeftHandSideExpression[?Yield, ?Await] of AssignmentExpression[+In, ?Yield, ?Await] ) Statement[?Yield, ?Await, ?Return]

content.body: but `for (using of of [1,2,3]) {}` _does_ parse as that: `using` is an identifier, the first `of` is the of in the for-of, and `of[1,2,3]` is an assignment expression of a computed property access on the identifier `of`
content.formatted_body: but for (using of of [1,2,3]) {} does parse as that: using is an identifier, the first of is the of in the for-of, and of[1,2,3] is an assignment expression of a computed property access on the identifier of

content.body: or is this language getting more cursed every day
The way we implemented it in Babel matches your reading
Why are the whitespace rules so incredibly lax/cursed, omg
